reviewText:
Ghostbusters: The Videogame is an over the shoulder third person shooter that not only has you blasting ghosts, but wrangling them down into traps. It stars the voice acting of all four original Ghostbusters, Dan Aykroyd, Harold Ramis, Bill Murray, and Ernie Hudson. Not just them, but other members of the cast, Annie Potts, William Atherton as William Peck, Brian Doyle-Murray as the Mayor and newcomer Alyssa Milano as Dr. Ilyssa Selwyn. You play the new fifth Rookie Ghostbuster, voiced by Ben Stiller. No I'm just kidding. He has no dialog, even though there are screams every so often. This is why you play the game, to immerse yourself in everything from the movies. To be in the firehouse between missions. To play what people call the third movie written by Aykroyd and Ramis. To be a real Ghostbuster shoulder to shoulder with them. I should mention there's no multiplayer component like the console versions.

You will rarely bust ghosts alone. Most of the time you're there with one, two, three or four of the Ghostbusters. They are competent partners and can really do anything you can do. Switch weapons, blast ghosts, wrangle them and trap them. In 10 hours of play, I never saw them get stuck on anything and in later parts, there is a lot to get stuck on. These partners can play the game without you, but that doesn't mean they leave you behind or lead the way. They stuck with you and let you lead the way. The Ghostbusters move as fast as you do, so you'll never have to wait for them.

Another thing they do well is revive. Your health slowly regenerates, but when you go down for the count, they'll pick you back up and you'll do the same for them! Sometimes that's a deal breaker for people. You can even be their medic if that's how you want to play. Let them do the work and they will, unless they're specifically hinting at what to do.

So when it comes to ghosts, there are two types, lesser ones you have to blast into vapor. The others, more difficult ghosts that you need to weaken them enough to wrangle them. Then with them wrangled, thrown around, so if they're scrambling to go right, you need to whip them to the left. When its time, you need to throw out a trap if there's not already one out. With a ghost weak enough, you and the other Ghostbusters need to pull them down into the trap and keep them from moving out of the radius of the vacuum where they are free again. It is all certainly a process that will make you feel like a real Ghostbuster, because it feels like work.

That's the game, so much of it feels like real work. You won't just run from area to area, you'll whip out your PKE meter and see in a first person night vision view. With the PKE meter out, you'll be guided to supernatural activity. There are things you'll need to find, such as clues, but also artifacts and collectables. I went through almost the entire game in PKE mode and I don't feel like there was anything special to find. Its not a fast mode, you'll need to follow the hot and cold signal, sometimes moving around rooms to find where the activity is coming from. The first person night vision is certainly a nice touch, its just not very quick.

The PKE is also your PDA. You'll use it to see what your objective is, upgrade weapons and view additional information on what you just scanned into the database. Everything can be upgraded once. From damage intensity to beam heat. You pay for it with money that you get for busting ghosts. Not just busting ghosts, but destruction. Its woven into the story that New York City pays for the repairs, so somehow you get the money for blowing up cars and shooting through walls.

When it comes to weapons, you start with the typical red proton stream and the Ghostbusters give you three others periodically to test out. A blue cryo beam, green slime slinger and a rapid fire sort of yellow pulse. The slime thrower can clear up black slime environmental hazards that will hurt you. It can also seal portals that lesser ghosts spawn. All four weapons share the same energy and if the beam gets too hot, you need to vent it (reload) or you're stuck having a cooldown for a longer period of time than a reload. If you cross proton beams too long, you'll get a warning, followed up by an explosive, damaging discharge. All four weapons make for a colorful light show all throughout the game.

The proton beam has a default fire button that, and a wrangler button lets you grab things including ghosts if they're weak enough. Then you can use a third button whip them around with a different button. Three buttons, one beam. On top of that there's an alt fire. The proton beam has a sort of grenade giant projectile, the cryo beam has a straight beam when normally its a shotgun blast of a beam for faster moving targets, the rapid fire beam just fires a second shot. Think of that as a right and left sort of firing. Just firing one rapid fire shot is slow, so you alt fire to double the speed.

Finally, there is the slime tether for the slime slinger. This is the only weapon that really feels fun. Alt fire it once to connect point A, then alt fire it again to connect point B. Watch as the two points quickly come together! This allows you to pull platforms together, move objects and generally derp around for the laughs.

There are a variety of enemies that you'll need different techniques to tackle. Rip shields away from some ghosts. Wrangle gargoyles and bash them into the ground. Slime tether flying cherubs to the ground and watch them smash. Cover black slime demons in green slime. Ghosts that possess people and the Ghostbusters, needing you to douse them in green slime to restore them. Some of the uncommon fights felt like they took way too long, especially the possessors. Can't shoot them, because they're in a Ghostbuster. Then still have to struggle to wrangle, throw them around and put them in a trap. The bosses were big with multiple parts. One you'd need to green slime it, because its covered in black slime, then tear its mask off, so the others can blast it.

The game had a few game breakers for me. Getting stuck in a luggage rack around my feet, preventing me from walking through a flooded hotel's tight spots. Not doing exactly what the Ghostbuster's told me to left them waiting for a ghost to put into the 'super slammer' ghost trap, when I put them in my own trap. The guys are very helpful with hints and clues.

As for the locations, the game will take you back through the first two movies. You'll visit the Sedgewick Hotel to recapture slimer, take on the Stay Puft Marshmallow Man in Times Square, visit the New York City Public Library and even the sewers that were once filled with slime. The game also takes you to new places I guess... like a ghost world with floating platforms that you need to slime tether together and timed running to avoid being beaten to death by books. Oh the game also takes you through a spooky graveyard. That's new right? Every location is spooky, but not scary or horrifying. There's no blood, just slime. The music is from the movie, but feels different like its a different performance and not the music straight from the movie like Ray Parker's theme song.

With everything said, the game felt like work. It was great to revisit mostly the first movie and have great voice acting from characters we know and love, but there are games that are more fun. Blasting ghosts to vapor was one thing, wrangling them is another. While the game is full of comedy written by two of the best and voice acted by three of the best, I didn't laugh out loud once. I understand that the jokes every 30 seconds were funny, I just didn't laugh. If this was the script for a third movie, I can't imagine it being a good movie. As for it being a good game... All this needed was to have the voice actors from the movie and a game that starts with Ray Parker's Ghostbusters theme and ends with Ray Parker's Ghostbuster's theme.

Who you gonna call...?
Well I am surprised to see Ghostbusters: The Videogame back on Steam. It got taken off about a year and a bit ago and has been A.W.O.L ever since. Well If you were ever keen to grab it, now would probably be a good time since there was apparently a problem getting keys issued for the game.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=344363919
To my surprise the game actually captures the spirit of the franchise perfectly (having been penned by Dan Ackroyd himself, one of the original creators of the Ghostbusters). Having all the actors reprise their digital selves is a blast and to hear the banter going back and forth between the characters reminded me of old friends, instantly transporting me back to the early eighties were as a kid with childlike sensibilities I lived in wonder of these fine ghost fighting folk so much so that I even wanted to be a Ghostbuster myself until I realized that movies were not real and that no real Ghostbusters of this variety actually existed.

The game picks up two years after the events that closed Ghostbusters 2 and involves an architect that goes by the name of Ivor Shando who is trying to bring another Great Destructor into the world. As stories of this nature go, its not the strongest and wouldn't have made that remarkable of a film if it were filmed as Ghostbusters 3 but for a game its more than fine.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=344364592
The graphics are quite lovely and vibrant throughout and many of the levels are an absolute blast to explore, although not tech pushing they do a serviceable job and manage to create an immerseful world that is immediately recognizable if you watched the movies. Controls were a bit awkward with the keyboard but once my xbox wireless controller was hooked in I had no problems whatsoever. The game can get quite challenging and frustrating in sections, especially towards the end were I was having hassles with the cherubs in the cemetery.

If I have one serious complaint it's that the rest of the Ghostbusting team (you get to play a nameless rookie and not one of the original characters) are a bit naff when it comes to actually fighting ghosts. They repeatedly get themselves into situations were they are downed and you have to rush over to revive them or else if you go down and there is no one to revive you the game ends and you have to restart from your save. It would have been nice if they had implemented a co-op feature which I understand after reading reviews was included in the console version. It's really a shame this did not make it into the PC version as I could think of nothing more awesome than co-oping a Ghostbuster's game. Anyway, classic case of PC gamers getting the short shrift yet again.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=344365772
All in all it was a great way to revisit the classic with even Slimer, Stay Pufft and the Librarian Ghost getting in on some of the digital action. As mentioned it's a pity we can't all hook up every once in a while to save New York from the terrors of the night but as a massive Ghostbusters fan (it's my favorite film from the eighties) it does more than just pay lip service to the fans. It actually turns out to be a worthy and rather well made action adventure game from a popular license. At it's current price of $9.99 its a steal considering the length and quality of the actual game.

reviewText:
I've enjoyed watching the Ghostbuster films as a kid, but never played any of the 8-bit and 16-bit games based on the franchise.
So, this is the very first GhostBusters game I've ever played and Finished to completion.

According to Dan Aykroyd, this game is considered as GhostBusters 3. It even carries on from GhostBusters 2, but with very slight inconsistencies. Does't affect the game though.

The story is good, written by Dan Aykroyd and the late Harold Ramis. I enjoyed it, all the trappings of GhostBusters are in it, including some great Venkman One-Liners.

Gameplay, I've enjoyed. At times the controls can be abit finicky, especially the Gears-Of-War-inspired run button that sometimes irritates me. The AI of the ghostbusters can be erratic to the point where it will cause you to die and restart to the last checkpoint. Towards the end of the game, specifically the Stone Angels by the Cemetary Gate, the difficulty is ramped up for no reason, it becomes the hardest section to beat and is needed to carry on. Very very weird.

Graphically, it is passable but dated by 2016 standards. Even though the game came out in 2009, it shows its age abit.
On my Nvidia 970, I have noticed that the framerate changes from 60 to 30, depending on what is happening onscreen. Sometimes a battle sequence is at 60fps and a walk through of a level is 30 and vice versa. This could be how the game was ported to PC though.

Audio, no issues here. Neither hate or love it, job gets done.

Is the game worth (as of 02-05-2016)US$10?
For huge fans of the franchise, yes. All your wims of GhostBustordium are met and slightly exceeded.
For everyone else, hold out for a discount. I bought mine for US$3 during a flash sale.

reviewText:
Finally got to it, and I really liked it. Now I'll admit I haven't seen Ghostbusters in few years, but it seemed very faithful to the spirit of the movie. Your character, a new guy joining Ghostbusters, doesn't speak at all, which is no problem. Bill Murray, on the other hand, speaks a lot and in such a ... uninterested... voice that is very funny.

Graphics are good (But then again, anything from 2009 that looked even 'okay' back then looks good to me now), I really liked how the proton pack is detailed, considering it covers your entire back and you'll be staring at it the whole game. Releasing the steam to cool down (basically reloading) was weirdly satisfying, so when there were no ghosts to bust, I sometimes shot up the scenery just to be able to cool down.

Environment is quite destructable, which is a need when you are busting ghosts in museums and luxury hotels.

Controls (w/ mouse) were a little awkward, but I got used to them after making some adjustments. (maxed up vertical sensitivity, lowered horizontal)

reviewText:
Ghostbusters: The Video Game takes place in 1991, about two years after Ghostbusters II. The Ghostbusters are now funded by the city of New York and they are well respected in the community. In fact, they have started recruiting new Ghostbusters, which is where you come in. You play as Rookie, a trainee whose real name the other Ghostbusters refuse to learn because they do not want to get too attached. You do not get much time to learn the ropes before a pulse of energy flows through the city, igniting paranormal activity like a wildfire.
Catching ghosts is lots of fun. Most of the ghosts in the game are beaten by just damaging them until they run out of health, but there are still a lot that require ghost traps. The process of wearing down these larger ghosts and dragging them into traps is incredibly satisfying. There's a decent variety of weapons aside from the basic proton stream, including a slime thrower and the really fun slime tether. You also come equipped with a PKE meter, which lets you get information about your environment and ghosts, much like the Scan Visor in Metroid Prime. All this equipment can be upgrade with money earned by catching, defeating, and scanning ghosts, as well as by finding collectibles throughout the game.
The characters look like the actor's they are based on. The effects for the proton pack are spot-on. The ghosts look great,with some interesting designs. The level designs are varied, ranging from areas straight from the movies to completely new, almost Lovecraftian environments. Everything looks good and creepy, and there is a lot of attention paid to detail.
Everything about the sound in this game is nearly perfect. Clearly, the voice acting is fantastic because it is the actual actors who are doing the voice actors.
The music sounds just like the movie, everything sounds right.
Ghostbusters: The Video Game offers an excellent opportunity to relive one of the greatest franchises of the 80s. It stays true to the movies it was based on while providing a nice twist to a standard video game genre. Whether you are a fan of the Ghostbusters or not, you will probably have fun with the few hours you will spend on this game.

Sound 9/10
Graphics 8/10
Gameplay 8/10
Atmosphere 9/10

reviewText:
A brilliant and challenging third-person action-adventure game - this newest installment of the Ghostbusters franchise was written and voiced by the original cast and fits perfectly into the canon, delivering more of the humor, character design, and laser-flinging action that we've come to love.

If you love Ghostbusters, don't hesitate to pick up this challenging and bonus-laden game, that will put you right into the movies without feeling contrived. If you're new to the franchise, prepare for laughs and spooks that only the Ghostbusters have been able to provide after all this time.

The game is roughly 10-hours long, features nicely animated cut-scenes, incredible likenesses of the cast, concept art, and plenty of hidden items to keep you entertained. This game doesn't feature much of the replayability of most modern games, and feels asthough the budget ran out after the campaign, but all the love and attention was put into making the story memorable and enjoyable, which is what you should be here for. In the end, I wholeheartedly recommend this game!

reviewText:
Story - Pretty nice for a Ghostbusters game, and was written by the original team behind the first two movies. This was intended to be Ghostbusters 3 and I'm glad to see them still shine. I wish there was a film adaptation, but with the guy who played Egon dead (may he rest in peace), it just isn't the same. I love the fact the game continues not long after the end of Ghostbusters 2. I don't want to spoil the plot but rest assured, it feels like Ghostbusters.

Gameplay - Bustin' ghosts never felt so right. There's several varieties of 2spooky4u ghosts that come in for melee attacks, ranged attacks, fire, slime, and so on. Chef ghosts haunt the kitchen, a fisherman and his boat haunt a seafood eattery, etc. In the Wii version there was also purple slime that could slow you down and make you less accurate and mobile. As a small side note you could also play as a female in the Wii version. You get upgrades along the way that are slowly introduced to the character that doesn't feel overwhelming. Ghosts are captured and dropped into the Ghost Containment Trap and you are given money. Money can be used to buy upgrades for your weapons and equipment.

You also have the PKE Meter which is used to track down hidden things, treasures, scan ghosts, and so on. All the things you find and collect are in display at the firehouse for you to see or interact with. My favorite is a pair of ghost bellbottom pants that play disco and walk around the firehouse. Even Vigo and the giant painting from Ghostbusters 2 is just propped up in the firehouse, and you can talk to them.

Ghosts and possessed things that are scanned are stored in a database for you to read up on and see their weaknesses.

You can destroy many things in the enviroment and that's cool. Nothing like blowing up millions of dollars worth of things that cannot be replaced in a museum.

Combat - Point the crosshair at the ghost, shoot beams at ghost, lay trap for ghost, catch ghost, and just know that bustin' makes you feel good. All ghosts have a weakness and exploiting the weakness makes them easier to trap. A lot of weaker/smaller ghosts, zombies, and things that are possessed don't need to be captured and are easy fodder to pick off. You can take damage in combat and taking enough damage knocks you out. A Ghostbuster can come revive and you can continue on your way. The Ghostbusters and their AI are for the most part, very stupid. Many times they will stand in the same place and take multiple hits and collapse in a funny heap, forcing you to revive them if you spare a moment. In most cases you'll want to keep them alive so anything that's a threat will target them instead of you.

Graphics, Models, Voice-acting- The graphics are fairly nice and consistent with the dark and spooky feeling of Ghostbusters. Some parts of the game are a little too dark and I found myself having to swap to the PKE meter just to see properly. I hear that there is a shadow rendering error, or some kind of display error that can cause the game to crash. I've yet to see that in my game. There's also some real world advertisements in-game. The only ones I could find were Doritos, back when they had the old logo.

Models look awesome and are ready to recognize. Everyone from Peter, to Egon, to the Stay-Puft Marshmallow Man look very good and accurate to their movie representation. Even the Proton Pack on your back looks VERY detailed and realistic.

Voice-acting is pretty good as well and I feel the Ghostbusters did a good job. My only real complaint is Bill Murray, in almost every bit of linework that he did, just sucked at it. He sounded very in character, but it wasn't difficult to imagine Bill inside the recording studio, bored while reading all the lines he had. Even his one-liners were a headache to listen to. Egon and the rest of the crew however did a very excellent job and I'm glad they got all the original actors to do their parts. I did find it strange that Louis (Rick Moranis) did not make an appearance, nor was mentioned outside of one line in-game. To be fair the helmet that he wore in the first movie after getting possessed is inside the firehouse.

Conversations don't feel awkward, forced, or weird. Lots of scientific mumbo-jumbo is tossed your way between Egon and Ray, which I found to be goofy.

Enviroments - A number of enviroments from a castle, the famous motel from the first movie, graveyard, the library from the first movie, and various other places look true to their origin. Or as true as they could be imagined. It felt very nostalgic to explore the library for some reason.

The firehouse is also in-game and acts as a sort of hub. Exploring the fire house reveals many of the things shown in the movies, as well as things you collected in missions. Janine, the secretary, is still there for the Ghostbusters and still takes calls and sets up appointments. In the upstairs area is the lab and where they sleep. They've got a Q*Bert arcade machine and next to it is Employee Of the Month" showing pictures of Bill Murray in various scenes of the movie
date: and I think one scene from Caddyshack. Of course the Ecto-1 is there

reviewText:
I just finished playing Ghostbusters: The Video game for the PC and wow what a ride. When I bought the game on Steam during their halloween sale I was happy to finally be able to play this game. I remember playing the demo on the PS3 when the game was about to come out and I thought to myself that this is a really good game. Sadly I wasn’t able to afford the game when it came out a couple of years ago.

I just have to say that I wasn’t expecting this game to have Dan Aykroyd, Bill Murray, Ernie Hudson, and Harold Ramis do the voices for their characters in the game. Hell I wasn’t even expecting Harold Ramis and Dan Aykroyd to be the writers of the game either. So once I read the title credits and saw those names, I knew it was going to be good.

The gameplay was actually great. Being able to use a Proton pack was exhilarating. I was able to control the stream wherever I wanted to, and I was able to destroy furniture and walls with the proton stream which was so cool. My favorite part was being able to use the ghost trap and capturing ghosts. The whole process of capturing was so spot on, that I actually felt like I was a ghostbuster. Using the Ecto-Goggles and PKE Meter to scan and identify ghosts was cool as well, but it just seemed like I had to use them to much. Besides using the Proton pack, ghost trap, PKE Meter, and Ecto-Goggles, there was also three other weapons that I was able to use. One of them being the Slime Blower from Ghostbusters II. The Slime Blower is used to discharge black slime and clear paths, as well as to take down ghosts that are weakened by green slime. Also there was a second function to the Slime Blower called Slime Tethers, which is used to either pull walls down or solving some puzzles. The next weapon that I was able to use was called a Dark Matter Generator. It worked like a weird shotgun and it was a little untrustworthy but good at short range. The second function of the dark matter generator was a stasis stream which when aimed and shot at a ghost for a certain period of time would crystallized the ghost and freeze them in place for a short while, while the other ghostbusters would damage the the frozen ghost. The third and final weapon would be the Composite Particle system. The two functions of this weapon is a Meson Collider and overload pulse. The Meson Collider worked like a sniper rifle, except with no scope. It fires a high powered particle stream like bullet and once it hits it's target, the Overload pulse comes in. The Overload Pulse, works when a ghost is tagged by the Meson Collider. When the Overload pulse is fired, it shoots out rapid fire particles and goes straight to where the tagged ghost is. If no target is made, it will continue to shoot rapid fire particles and can be directed to any ghost.

So adding on a couple of weapons, one already known, and two which are brand new, it was cool to mess around with these in the game. What made me happy about these weapons was that every time I got a new weapon, Egon (Harold Ramis character), would explain what the weapons would do and the scientific reasoning behind them. To me hearing the explanations of the weapons made it fit into the Ghostbuster universe perfectly.

The ghosts are of course the main enemies of the game. There was a wide variety of ghosts from chefs to librarians to Slimer, and of course The Stay-Puft Marshmallow Man. Each with their own weakness and abilities, which made the game more challenging. Some would need to get hit by a certain weapon to make it easier to catch, some would need to be destroyed by a Proton stream. All in all, it made the game fun.

The levels were good as well. Nothing looked like it wasn’t finished. The architecture on some of the levels were phenomenal, and the way everything looked, looked right out of an actual Ghostbuster movie. It made the game much more enjoyable.

In the end, the whole game acted like a brand new Ghostbuster movie. It felt like this is what Ghostbusters III would have been. I had a blast playing this game and I wish there was another one being made, but sadly Harold Ramis died this year and yet we still have Dan Aykroyd as the secondary writer, it wouldn't be the same without Ramis. I’ve played many movie to game adaptations and yes there are many that are terrible, but Ghostbusters: The Video Game was a very well made, well polished game that I wouldn’t mind playing over again.

reviewText:
A love song to the fans of the Ghostbusters franchise and what is essentially the third movie, as well as the last gathering of all the original Ghostbusters since the passing of Raimis.

It's well voiced and it looks very good. You play as a silent but otherwise visually emotive recruit who helps the Ghostbusters out through their missions as well as helping them test new proton pack equipment. There's a solid story flow which feels very true to the nature of the franchise, and it maintains continuity instead of making up random Hollywood revisionist ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. This is largely due to Akroyd and Raimis having written the script. On a nice note, Winston gets a lot of lines now instead of being relegated more to the background. The only sad exclusion is the lack of Rick Moranis' character, Tully, although a nod is given to his character's existence still.

I really enjoyed the experience the game provides. You really feel like one of the team, learning alongside them, while not coming off like some all important Mary Sue or a hapless yutz. The only downside is the controls are a little odd in terms of aiming. I was never able to get the mouse speed and sensitivity to a sweet spot. That said, it wasn't anything impossible to deal with.

reviewText: Batman: Arkham Asylum might be most often held up as *the* seminal licensed game, but dang it all if Ghostbusters doesn't come close to topping it. The third-person shooting is good, but not mind-blowing, and though the ghost-capturing action is a refreshingly hectic change of pace from the typical goon gallery of most shooters, it can get a little frustrating and repetitive as the game wears on. Nevertheless, thanks to a fun and funny script, excellent voice acting from the movie actors, and countless winks and nods to franchise centrepieces, Ghostbusters captures all the enjoyment of the films while still being a heartily enjoyable game to play.

reviewText:
Ghostbusters: The Videogame is a third-person shooter. As the newest recruit of the Ghostbuster team, you follow Egon, Ray, Peter and Winston as they discover the source of the disasters that have struck New York City in their past adventures.

Pros: This is the third movie everyone have always wanted, the scripts by Harold Ramis and Dan Aykroyd is spot on, and all the main voice actors return including William Atherton as Walter Peck. The game looks and sounds great. The attention to details is staggering, including the incredible amount of lore and fan service in the Firehouse. You actually feel like you’re one of the Ghostbusters as they interact with you and each other.

Cons: The game is short, and you can easily complete it AND get all the secret collectibles in 10 hours. The music, limited to the score available in the two movies, can get repetitive. When swarmed by ghosts, you may find yourself spending the better part of the encounter helping your buddies back on their feet, which can get frustrating.

Verdict: ★★★★☆ - Next on your list!

If you’re any bit of a Ghostbusters fan, GET THIS GAME! Sure, its length will leave you wanting more, because it is so good! This game was made with love and attention to detail, very few movie game will ever be as spot-on as Ghostbuster: The Videogame. Bustin' has never made me felt this good!

—————————————————————————
This was just my opinion.

reviewText:
TL;DR Version: If you're Ghostbusters' fan, then you must get this game. If you're not... well, watch the movies first and get back here, if you became one of.


Story
Story is written by Dan Aykroyd & Harold Ramis (Ray & Egon), so expect 100% authenticity and relation with both Ghostbusters movies. Many think, including myself, this game as Ghostbusters 3 movie.

10/10


Sound
Ghostbusters' voices performed by original actors themselves: Bill Murray, Dan Aykroyd, Harold Ramis. Classic dialogues, jokes etc.
Same theme song by Ray Parker Jr.
Same sounds of proton packs, traps, Ecto-1.

What can be better?.. NOTHING!
10/10


Graphics
Game is almost 5 years old now, so it is hard to judge. When you are first time launching the game, picture looks ♥♥♥♥♥♥. But when you get used to it, you start to find artwork really beautiful.
Especially I like character design. You see Peter Venkman on the screen and you believe he is Bill Murray. Don't know, maybe it is more due to voice acting and classic dialogues, but even if game graphics doesn't make it feel better, then at least it doesn't make it worse.
Graphical effects are primitive, but look nice. Same as in movie.

Good artwork but lowres. Is this due to age or bad engine's optimization that lead to detail cuts?
8/10. Bring HD textures and I'll give 10.


Gameplay
Why I put gameplay to the end? Because this game should be treated more as a movie rather than as a game. There are a lot of cut-scenes in the game. I would say even more: there are some cut-gameplay put inside a movie. Don't get me wrong - this is a good thing. First because those cut-scenes are interesting to watch, especially if you're Ghostbusters fan like I am. Seconds, the gameplay, which is put between those cut-scenes, is interesting too. It's not like in other game, where you need to spend 5 minutes of watching one cut-scene, then ten times press 'E', then watch another one, which you can't skip. Btw, you can skip cut-scenes in Ghostbusters, if you want to. But I didn't. Cuz they are cool ;)

Enough about movies. Let's talk about gaming. This isn't an arcade action game. It is ghost hunting simulator. A dream of my childhood: you got a proton pack on your back, PK-meter and a ghost trap - go hunt your ghost, cadet! Wow, cool!... wait, how am I supposed to do it? This game is awesome!  It looks great, plays well, and is downright entertaining.

Your weapons cause massive destruction to anything they get close to.  The controls were loose and tricky, aiming was exceptionally difficult, which only made it even MORE fun (This IS dangerous and highly volatile experimental equipment you are using after all).  You get 9 different weapons to juggle by the end!

It's very refreshing from the usual *point/shoot/kill* mechanic as you first have to SCAN the ghost several times just to figure out what to use on it!  The puzzles aren't brain busting, but still enjoyable.

This game would be creepy and horrifying if it wasn't so comical, lighthearted, and just FUNNY.

It really felt like I was a part of the movie.  The scene based checkpoint system serves it well.

I recommend this to anyone with a beating heart.  No prior knowledge of Ghostbusters necessary, but it might help you get some of the jokes.

reviewText:
Ghostbusters: The Videogame is fun, but that doesn't mean it's a masterpiece or anything. It exceeds in writing as Dan Akroyd and Harold Ramis actually wrote it, which is notable given the amount of dialog given explaining the science and technology. And Bill Murray and Ernie Hudson also reprise their roles alongside Ramis and Akroyd. This is the good Ghostbusters game you should be playing. Also, Akroyd considers it canon to the film franchise as this was initially meant to be the third film.

It's 1991, the plot in the game involves the Ghostbusters crew taking on a rookie/intern and start by showing him the ropes. Things go bad when the city experiences a shockwave sent from the history museum where an exhibit on Gozer is supposed to be opening up soon. Most of the exhibit's pieces were donated by the Shandor estate. If you recall anything from the first film, Shandor was an insane physician. Well, he's the primary villain in this game. You'll encounter ghosts seen from the films, new ghosts, and bizarre areas. I don't really wanna spoil anything. Oh, and Max von Sydow reprises his voice as Vigo. You can find the painting of him in the firehouse and interact with him as much as you'd like.

The graphics are decent. I mean, I'm playing it six years post release so it kind of goes to show how far technology has come that I'm just calling it decent. Then again, the first Crysis still looks amazing today and that was 2007. But that's also an unfair comparison as Terminal Reality isn't well known for being a graphics powerhouse and Ghostbusters was probably their last great game before they shut down in 2013. Anyway, the special effects with the power equipment and sound designs were great.

Pretty great game overall though.

8.3/10

reviewText:
At the time of this review, the cast of 'Ghostbusters' reboot was recently announced. Given there is no chance of a 'Ghostbusters 3' starring the original cast (rest in peace, Mr. Ramis), playing this game felt like finding closure through interactive nostalgia.

The main selling point of 'Ghostbusters: The Video Game' is that it brought Bill Murray, Dan Aykroyd, Harold Ramis and Ernie Hudson back together as the Ghostbusters, with Annie Potts and William Atherton joining them as Janine Melnitz and Walter Peck respectively. Also, Aykroyd and Ramis co-wrote the game's story, making this as complete a 'Ghostbusters' experience as you can get right now. There were also plenty of cameos and references to other otherworldly creatures throughout the game. With you playing as a new (nameless and speechless) recruit of the Ghostbusters, the game would make you feel that you are part of their wonderful world.

For a game that came out back in 2009, 'Ghostbusters: The Video Game' still looks pretty great about 5 years later. The set pieces were beautifully designed and rendered, and the proton pack energy streams still look fanastic. Despite borrowing the basic game mechanics from 'Gears of War', the game felt very unique mainly due to the proton pack weapons. In fact, zapping, capturing and trapping ghosts using these weapons added an extra level of challenge and fun to what could have been otherwise a generic third-person shooter.

You can tell that the creators of 'Ghostbusters: The Video Game' had put a lot of thought and care into designing the game. They also made it quite challenging in some parts. There are 3 difficulty levels: Casual, Experienced, and Professional. I've found myself losing often in two or three of the boss fights playing at the Experienced level. While my mission failures were at times due to the Ghostbusters A.I., making my experience frustrating, I did feel compelled to keep going. Things did get easier once I purchased upgrades for my weapons.

The game, while great, is by no means without flaws. The biggest one is actually having Bill Murray coming back to play Peter Venkman. In the movies, he was energetic, sarcastic and at times obnoxious. In the game, Bill Murray's performance was very inconsistent -- sounding lethargic and disinterested in one spot, and very true-to-character in another. It was quite disappointing to say that Bill Murray's Peter Venkman added little to the key moments of the game. Thankfully, other original cast members gave it their all.

Some reviews back in the 2009 gave the PC version of 'Ghostbusters: The Video Game' a mediocre score in part due to the lack of multiplayer mode. While a multiplayer mode would have been welcomed, I sincerely do not think the game should have been penalized so greatly because of its absence. 5 years later, 'Ghostbusters: The Video Game' still holds up well. I highly recommend this game to those who enjoy third-person shooters, but I think it is fans of the original films who will enjoy it most.

My final verdict is that this game is great, even though it's a movie game.

I loved playing this game, it was really great.  But a few things to keep in mind.

This is Ghostbusters, not a new idea or franchise.  The thrill of this game is getting to strap a proton pack on your back and hang out with Peter, Ray, Egon, and Winston.  If you aren't a fan of Ghostbusters, there's no point in playing this.

This is a single-player third-person adventure/shooter with AI teammates who assist you.

The good is that the story is written by Harold Ramis (RIP) and Dan Aykroyd, and feels very much like the movies did, especially the first movie.  Some people have called this the third movie.  It is more or less a direct follow-up to the original story, revisiting Gozer and Ivo Shandor, and why they were almost able to cause an apocalypse.  I felt a bit of excitement seeing they included the old, grainy Colombia logo just like in the movies, and the game menu resembles the DVD menu.  The bad part of this is while many characters returned, two were conspicuously absent.  Dana Barrett and Louis Tully are not in the game, but Louis is mentioned in passing at the end of the game.

The main tool of the game is the proton pack and trap.  And this they got completely right, using them looks and feels like the movies.  Like in Ghostbusters 2, the packs can also be equipped with slime, but unlike the pinkish mood slime, it is the traditional ectoplasm green.  Additional tools can be added to the proton pack as the game progresses.  The only letdowns are that you cannot drive Ecto-1, and that the PKE meter quickly gets annoying.

The gameplay itself is satisfying, but not great.  You aren't playing Half-Life 2, or anything in the ballpark of great games.  It is a mostly linear game, with somewhat repetitive enemies, and it overuses some tools (after awhile I start to wish I never heard of a slime tether!).  Some concepts, such as property damage claims, are not explained and typically irrelevant.  The game uses a checkpoint system and auto-healing, which some gamers have strong feelings about.  It isn't particularly challenging, either.  The game is also fairly short, only taking a few hours to play.

The enjoyment mostly comes from the storyline, acting, and a bit of wish fulfillment, because what kid in the 80's didn't want to strap on a proton pack and hunt down ghosts?  If you enjoyed the original movie, and you want to play an interactive story, this is an enjoyable game.  If you want a challenge, and you haven't seen the movies, look elsewhere.  Or go watch the movies, because they are f***ing awesome.

reviewText:
An Excellent Ghostbusters 3


Any longtime fan of Ghostbusters has undoubtedly gone through the list of sound bytes about what's going on, if anything, with Ghostbusters 3. It's not happening because Bill Murray doesn't want anything to do with it, it's happening anyway, now Bill Murray has something to do with it after all, the scripts haven't been good enough for Reitman and Akroyd, etc. Harold Ramis' passing hasn't helped matters, but even that has been subject to a back-and-forth, with the original Ghostbusters supposedly planned as cameos in whatever form Ghostbusters 3 takes so they can pass the torch.

Given how long fans have waited, it's nice to see a game specifically set after Ghostbusters 2. The plot revisits several elements from the movies, but for the most part it takes their minor details to expand on instead of rehashing the major ones; we get to see more on the very first ghost the Ghostbusters hilariously failed to bust in the library before they even had their gear, and more on the history of the hotel Slimer was caught in. This is an effective way to provide something that the fans will care about, while still having an excuse to let the characters talk about background information so someone who hasn't seen the movies won't be confused about why these things are important. It thus avoids how the second movie is widely regarded to have failed, where it redid the original's story arc with different pronouns (Vigo being an obvious stand-in for Gozer, the Ghostbusters having to start from scratch, etc.) While Gozer, as a major plot point of one of the movies, is a rehash by virtue of the movie covering pretty much all there was to cover, it turns out to be a lead-in to expanding on yet another minor element as a resolution. Given that this is a classic franchise and most of the audience is likely to be made of fans anyway, being newcomer-friendly may be pointless, but it's still nice to see writing of a high enough quality that it actually puts in the effort to maintain continuity while still avoiding lockout. Special mention goes to Walter Peck; the original movie is one of the very few things that have ever made the unfriendly, opposing bureaucrat character interesting and amusing instead of so ridiculous that it’s painful to watch (moviegoers who have endured Transformers 2 know exactly how bad this character archetype is when the writers both throw it in because it’s expected to be there and let the subplot run on for way too long.) The game follows through, giving the character a reason for being in the plot beyond just being an opposing force the good guys must awkwardly circumvent. Even the silent protagonist has some effort put into it; the Rookie is given enough in the way of facial expressions and body language for him to have actual character instead of just being the usual, lazy, blank slate.

The game was obviously a labor of love. All the small details help to recreate the flavor that made the movies so memorable, from the absurd occult artifacts to Egon's blase reaction in the face of pulse-pounding terror to Janine being perfectly in-character. Long-time fans who know the supplementary material (particularly children of the '80s who grew up with The Real Ghostbusters") will find plenty of nods to various parts of the franchise. Poor art direction could have easily ruined this

reviewText: It's rare that a movie-licensed game does anything but mud up the overall impression of its source material. Ghostbusters: The Videogame is one of the rare exceptions. It lives up to the expectations of the fans of the old movies and animated TV-series. Better yet, it's more than just a functional tack-on and reliving of the movies. It offers its own new characters, environments and stories into the mix. Okay, so it's functionally a third person shooter with the Ghostbusters theme firmly attached on top, but is that really a bad thing? I can honestly not think of a better way to make a game about the ghostbusters and their escapades. It's as quirky and funny as the movies, and has as many encounters with a variety of ghosts as are featured throughout the animated series.\n\nIf you have any affection at all for the Ghostbusters license, even if it's just a tiny little bit, then go and buy this game now that it's finally back on Steam.

reviewText: I still remember when Ghostbusters came to the silver screen back in the mid 80s. I loved the humour of this supernatural comedy movie at the time, and like every kid back then I really got into the books, music and even the animated series.  However to this day there has not been that many games that successfully capture the feel of the movie, sure there been several attempts of a Ghostbusters video game, however all the ones I played from the early 1980s 8bit version to the recent games based on Real Ghostbusters always lacked something.  To me this game is definetly been created with love to the fans and it is what Ghostbusting should be about.  Its far from perfect though, and some of the level designs are annoying as are some of the graphic textures seem unfinnished in areas.  Saying that though, what this game gets right it does well.  The voice acting is fine and well delivered by the original movie cast, as are some of the music cues are taken directly from the movie.  In short if you loved the Ghostbusters movie, or followed the animated show then this is a must buy for you. (edit) After playing more of this game I can see where they put the love into this game, and it is definetly a love letter to their fans and has so many nods to both the animated series and the movies.

reviewText:
Dan Akroyd referred to this game as being Ghostbusters III.

You play the game as a new recruit the Ghostbusters hired somewhere down the line between the end of GB2, and the beginning of this game. The character you play as is a standard mute hero with almost no discernable personality. He constantly gets shoved off to the side or the background during cutscenes. It's almost funny, and would be if you weren't the one playing him. I just felt bad for him after a while.

Since your character you play as gets shafted like this, it starts making one wonder why they didn't just do away with a trainee character, and let you play as your choice of one of the four original Ghostbusters.

The story was downright fantastic, it followed the events of the second and first movies phenominally. Some of the story-driving bosses may have been a tad too 'demonic' for something out of Ghostbusters, but they still would somehow maintain a Ghostbusters-esque personality. Most other ghosts were creative enough that I'd have expected to see them in the Ghostbusters universe. Most of the swarming type ghosts were not very inspired, and in another instance a blue, and a white ghost that were introduced looked like something that got ripped off from Luigi's Mansion. Despite the swarmers and the other afformentioned ghosts, there were more than enough creative ghosts to overshadow the mediocre or downright stupid ones. Usually the more creative of the ghosts were even just using the swarmers as an attack.

The gameplay reminded me a little bit of Bioshock mixed with some other FPS like Killzone, except you play in the third-person. Unlike the story, the gameplay was NOT very inspired, but it was not terrible. The gameplay was generic at its worst, elements were taken from other more popular games. They could have taken gameplay mechanics from much MUCH worse places than Half-Life 2, Killzone (or other shooters like it), or Bioshock right?

My personal rating for Ghostbusters: The Video Game from 1-10 in a nutshell is as follows.

Story: 10 it follows its own source material extremely well, there are many cameos from past ghosts, and all the original actors are present, and voice act well.

Gameplay: 6.5 due to the generic and uninspired quality of it. However, the new attacks you get conform to the Ghostbusters universe, and the designers did a GREAT job of integrating them into the proton pack without making them look out of place.

reviewText:
If you're a Bill Murray fan, or a Ghostbusters fan in general, then this game isn't all bad. The script is great. My wrath comes down primarily on Atari.

This game has a disgusting memory leak. I've been playing first and third person shooters for years, and have a lot of control with them, on a pretty good gaming PC with specialized hardware that could not exist at the time that Ghostbusters was made. All the same, I cannot play it above Casual/Cinematic, because of the awful slowdowns. A memory leak is a serious problem, and it was holistically ignored by Atari QA, even to this day.

Art is amazing, script is wonderful, and outside of a glitch with cutscenes the sound is synchronized. The programming leads to slowdowns that quickly make the game unplayable. I believe I have gotten around most of them by exiting to the menu; then reloading your game and continuing. However, save points are automatic and without notification, and doing this causes you to jump back to the last checkpoint. They are sporadic at best.

If you can get it for three bucks, it might be worth it. I would not pay anything more for the game.

reviewText:
After playing this game through on the XBox 360 and thoroughly enjoying both the multiplayer and single player campaign, buying this game upon release was a no-brainer, as the thought of playing it with the mouse and keyboard made me really excited to get good and climb the multiplayer ghost-hunting ranks.

I paid £30 for this game.

The reason the game is currently £6.99 is because the multiplayer isn't even in the PC version of the game.

I'm not even kidding.

We get single player ONLY.

Oh and about playing with the mouse and keyboard... Forget it.

This game has the worst reverse mouse acceleration I've ever used in a game, and was the sole reason I originally bought an XBox pad for my PC.

This game's campaign is playable with a pad, but if you don't like using one, pass this one up.

Moving the mouse slowly causes no movement to register in-game at all.

What the slimy green ****, Atari?

I have scoured forums for hours looking for a fix for the controls so I can use the mouse and keyboard properly, but there is literally nothing. The acceleration is coded in to the engine itself, and the algorithm that translates your mouse movements to in-game action are NOT bypassable, no matter what you try.

I've only had a few bugs, and only one of them was game-breaking, forcing a restart of the entire chapter, but it only seems to be happening to a few of us.

This game runs perfectly on my Windows 10 system besides the issue with the controls, although if you wish to run it in a window, you're going to need DXWind or WinExp to force it in to one, although the game becomes very unstable, so keep that in mind if you plan to stream it.

If you can find this game for sale online somewhere cheap, get it. If you love the Ghostbusters, and don't mind using a gamepad to play a 3rd person game, you're going to have a blast. I wouldn't be able to comfortably say that this game is even worth £6.99 in the state it's in.

reviewText:
Gameplay: Entertaining, though a bit repetitive.

Controls: Customizable, game suffers from mouse smoothing which makes aiming/viewing sluggish, movement also feels floaty and the jumping, while decent for evading, is a complete joke for navigation purposes.

Graphics: Not bad, a little underwhelming in some areas (ie. Walking in front of the Ecto-1's headlamps does not illuminate your character or cast your shadow)

Sound: Awesome, from the voice actors to the sound effects.

Game length: Somewhat short, finished it in about 6 hours including hunting for collectibles and cleaning all the black slime.

Replay value: Very little, there are a few collectibles to gather and a weapon upgrade progression.

Performance: Decent, good stable framerates and no CTD bugs, only downside would be the horrible loeading times.

All in all it was enjoyable game, hearing all the familiar sounds and voices had me running down memory lane, Iwas even moving my head about while the theme music played from time to time.

Pick it up if you are a Ghostbusters fan and wish to star in your own Ghostbusters movie, otherwise give this game a pass.

reviewText:
I'm a fanboy so maybe me saying that this is a great game isn't exactly valid, but I very much enjoyed Ghostbusters.

While I've seen some people complain about the elongated ghost catching sequences, there really aren't so many of them that it bogs the game down.

The humor is all there, with the exception of Bill Murray: he's very scripted.  Plenty of Ghostbuster throwbacks, but these extend almost to the point of annoyance.

The story is pretty neat and, as it turns out, was more along the lines of an original draft for the first Ghostbusters movie.  This script was scrapped for being too alien for audiences to connect with, and instead the movies were based very strongly in New York with far less fantastical elements.

I mean, hey, I felt like a ghostbuster in this game and that's pretty solid.  I heartily recommend playing it.

reviewText:
This is pretty much a love letter to Ghostbuster fans, plus it's pretty much Ghostbusters 3.

You play as an unamed rookie who just joined the Ghostbusters, you sadly cannot create your character like in Saints Row or Sims, but it's a very nice touch instead of forcing a new character in, plus you cannot play as a Girl so female fans have to mod this game if you want to play as a girl, I also love the fact they just call you rookie and nothing else.

The game is third person and controls really well, however I would have prefered to be in first person to make it feel like I was the new Ghostbuster, rather then PLAYING as the new Ghostbuster, but overall the controls are great except for sprinting and jumping, they are both the same button, pressing space gives you a delayed jump, while holding space makes you sprint, you can change it luckly.

The graphics are very impressive and the humour is spot on, it REALLY feels like I'm there helping the others, it REALLY feels like I'm there catching Slimer, honestly if this was on Oculus Rift it would be bang on perfect.

Overall it's a must have, the last good Ghostbuster game we got was on the SEGA Genesis/Mega Drive, and it took 19 years for another good Ghostbuster game to pop up, and it's been worth the wait.

reviewText:
I first played this game on PS3 when it came out in 2009 and as a life long Ghostbusters fan I loved it to death. I just bought it on sale here on Steam so I could play it in high resolution with mouse and keyboard controls and while the port has some rough edges to it I still love the game. There are some frame rate issues in one or two places, the game seems to forget some of the upgrades you purchase between gaming sessions and the mouse acceleration is beyond horrible. It is also completely missing the multiplayer mode that the original console versions had. Apart from these cons the game is every bit as good as I remembered. The original cast are all there with the exception of Rick Moranis and Sigourney Weaver as their characters do not appear in the game. The game was written by Dan Aykroyd and Harold Ramis so it has some real funny dialogue.

The gameplay itself is excellent. Ghostbusting is challenging but rewarding and the trapping mechanic is fun. There's an upgrade system for the proton pack that has a real impact on gameplay. You also have Tobin's Spirit Guide for reading about all the different spooks for tips about their weaknesses etc. The graphics hold up surprisingly well. The game looks really good at 1080p. There are some rough textures here and there but nothing major. The sound is also excellent. The sound effects from the proton pack are great as well as the ambient sounds. Music is awesome.



All in all it's a great game with a few flaws. Highly recommended for fans of Ghostbusters.

reviewText:
A third person shooter that's great for fans of the various shooter genres and fans of ghostbusters alike.

More in-depth:

This is a combination of fast-paced tps style gameplay and the occational section horror. It has a unique combat system, taking full advantage of the source material it stayed true to in order to create an interesting dynamic in combat, while not being overly difficcult or extremely easy. And to top it all off, it comes with many memorable characters from the movies, and really tells an interesting story.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Story:
The story, as stated by many, feels like the third movie that every one wanted but never got. It takes you to many inconic locations, and faces you against iconic foes all over again.

You play as a new rookie Ghostbuster, who just so happens to be the new test subject for all the new equipement that could possibly blow you to New Jersey...
------------------------------------------------------
Gameplay:
The shooting mechanics consist of many steams and modes. You have red, blue, green, and yellow steams, as well as the regular shooting mode and the rangling mode to capture.

Red is the standard, and what you start off with. It does decent damage and has good accuracy over any distance, so it feels balanced.

Blue does a lot more damage, but is really only short range. So I recommend it for crowd control and other close range combat circumstances.

Green is the slime blower, and is required for getting rid of black slime on environment as well as on monsters.

Yellow works as a low damage homing shot. So it's useful for finding enemies you've lost in large areas, as well as being practically required for a certain late game boss fight.

The regular shooting stream mode allows you to do damage to a ghost's PKE (health).

The capture stream is required for capturing ghosts by throwing them into the traps you place down.
------------------------------------------------------
Graphics:
The game looks good, even today. However the CGI cutscenes paired with the much less acurate models and animation of the regular engine clash a bit.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Overall a very good game that I highly recommend!

Highly recommended to fans of the ghostbusters film series. This is essentially the third movie that never was, written by Dan Akroyd and (the now late) Harold Ramis, who ofcourse wrote and starred in the original movies. All the actors from the films return to provide they're voices and likeness.

reviewText:
I first played this game on PS3 when it came out in 2009 and as a life long Ghostbusters fan I loved it to death. I just bought it on sale here on Steam so I could play it in high resolution with mouse and keyboard controls and while the port has some rough edges to it I still love the game. There are some frame rate issues in one or two places, the game seems to forget some of the upgrades you purchase between gaming sessions and the mouse acceleration is beyond horrible. It is also completely missing the multiplayer mode that the original console versions had. Apart from these cons the game is every bit as good as I remembered. The original cast are all there with the exception of Rick Moranis and Sigourney Weaver as their characters do not appear in the game. The game was written by Dan Aykroyd and Harold Ramis so it has some real funny dialogue.

The gameplay itself is excellent. Ghostbusting is challenging but rewarding and the trapping mechanic is fun. There's an upgrade system for the proton pack that has a real impact on gameplay. You also have Tobin's Spirit Guide for reading about all the different spooks for tips about their weaknesses etc. The graphics hold up surprisingly well. The game looks really good at 1080p. There are some rough textures here and there but nothing major. The sound is also excellent. The sound effects from the proton pack are great as well as the ambient sounds. Music is awesome.



All in all it's a great game with a few flaws. Highly recommended for fans of Ghostbusters.

reviewText:
A third person shooter that's great for fans of the various shooter genres and fans of ghostbusters alike.

More in-depth:

This is a combination of fast-paced tps style gameplay and the occational section horror. It has a unique combat system, taking full advantage of the source material it stayed true to in order to create an interesting dynamic in combat, while not being overly difficcult or extremely easy. And to top it all off, it comes with many memorable characters from the movies, and really tells an interesting story.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Story:
The story, as stated by many, feels like the third movie that every one wanted but never got. It takes you to many inconic locations, and faces you against iconic foes all over again.

You play as a new rookie Ghostbuster, who just so happens to be the new test subject for all the new equipement that could possibly blow you to New Jersey...
------------------------------------------------------
Gameplay:
The shooting mechanics consist of many steams and modes. You have red, blue, green, and yellow steams, as well as the regular shooting mode and the rangling mode to capture.

Red is the standard, and what you start off with. It does decent damage and has good accuracy over any distance, so it feels balanced.

Blue does a lot more damage, but is really only short range. So I recommend it for crowd control and other close range combat circumstances.

Green is the slime blower, and is required for getting rid of black slime on environment as well as on monsters.

Yellow works as a low damage homing shot. So it's useful for finding enemies you've lost in large areas, as well as being practically required for a certain late game boss fight.

The regular shooting stream mode allows you to do damage to a ghost's PKE (health).

The capture stream is required for capturing ghosts by throwing them into the traps you place down.
------------------------------------------------------
Graphics:
The game looks good, even today. However the CGI cutscenes paired with the much less acurate models and animation of the regular engine clash a bit.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Overall a very good game that I highly recommend!

reviewText:
Never hearing of this game before this year's summer sale I really wonder what I was doing in 2009 to never have played such a  suprisinly good game. Don't Get me wrong this isn't some perfect game, its just so suprising that this was a positive moive to videogame translation which has had terrible results in the past. Part of what makes this such a success where other moive based game tie ins have failed is the cast is all there. Dan Akroid, Bill Murry, Harold Ramis, and Erine Hudson voiced their respective roles. Not only did the cast pull ogether to voice the characters Dan Akroid, and Harold Ramis wrote the story themselves. I knew I was in for a classic ghostbusters expirience, truly the thrid installment of the series.

As for the gameplay its a third person shooter, with some intresting twists. For example wrangling, after weaking the ghost you put it in a capture beam and throw it around the room until you can trap it. There are upgrades purchaseable through your PKE and new weapons like the slimer or stasis stream. The story is pretty straight forward, its Ghostbusters, its a fun light-hearted expirience that is told through multipule cut-scences and banter amongst the voiced characters.

All in all it is so unbelieveably good compared to its NES counterpart, and it has aged fairly well (given todays standards). I reccomend it to anyone who is a fan of Ghostbusters or is looking for a more unique take on thrid person shooters.

reviewText:
Good

+Very true to the original movies

+Voice actors include original actors from the movies

+Includes a lot of familiar places from the movies, including Ghostbusters' office building

+Proton pack looks and feels good

+Catching a ghost is well executed and feel awesome


Bad

-Plot is a bit awkwardly written, possibly only to serve a purpose to let players experience some of the original movies' setups

-Catching multiple ghosts is irritating. Catching the first ghost was awesome experience, but after that, the game feeds you ghosts in groups, and it is surprisingly frustrating. Weakening and catching a ghost needs time and concentration, and you don't have either when other ghosts or possessed companions are attacking you.

-Companion AI is below average. They are either blocking your way to shoot monsters / ghosts, or they have been knocked down and you need to go help them up, which eats away further more of the time that you would rather need to weaken ghosts.

-Unnecessary upgrades to proton pack. Rather than giving tactical options to gameplay, proton pack upgrades just makes ghost fighting even more annoying when you need to switch back and forth between them on some occasions.

-Gameplay leans heavily on the mediocre ghost fighting. PK meter has been added, but rather than giving any depth or atmosphere to the game, PK meter is mostly just a tool to trigger obvious plot points. I.e. something on the door prevents us from going though. Scan the door, problem gets solved, continue to the next ghost fight.



TL;DR -Ghostbusters is a mediocre game with flaws that only a fan of the original franchise can forgive.

reviewText:
Im not going to beat around the bush Ghostbusters: The Videogame originally began its life as Ghostbusters 3. After Years and years of languishing in development hell in Hollywood due to a mixture of budget issues and cast unavailability it seemed that the film would never be made and we would never get one more outing with the guys who came, saw and kicked ♥♥♥.

This game is quite literally the 3rd ghostbusters script only with certain physical script directions moved off the original cast and onto you: The Rookie.

Is this a good story? Oh my good god yes. This is an almost perfect recapturing of the original vibe of the ghostbusters films and with good reason Written by the late great Harold Ramis and Dan Akroyd it simply oozes that late 80’s early 90’s feel that the first two ghostbusters films so readily projected. This. And only this. Is the reason you should pick this game up. Get it in the sale, set the difficulty to easy and just enjoy the cut scenes (All of which are voiced by the original cast I might add) if you’ve ever wanted a 3rd ghostbusters film. This game is right up your street. Better yet, go to youtube where im almost certain that someone has supercut all the important gameplay moments and cut scenes together into one coherent film.

Why suggest going to look it up online? Or worse still to just play the game through on easy to get the great great film that plays in between? Because the game elements of this video game are border sadistic. It was at some point in the third act when I fell into the basement of a castle and had to spend the best part of an hour wandering around aimlessly till I  found Ernie Hudson that I realised; I just played a section of gameplay that would be written out of a film. And that’s the 2nd biggest problem with this as a game. You only really play cool ghostbustery moments about 30% of the time, the rest of the time your wandering about down corridors…in a film you’d cut away to help keep pacing up but in this game its almost like it actively encourages these boring, long and utterly nerve destroying moments…

Add to this that at random points in the game it likes to utterly bombard you with ghosts for no real reason other than to insta-kill you and that the AI is really not very well programmed to deal with these situations (A key issue because the AI in this game are essential to you not getting a game over) and you have a real problem game ultimately…controls feel lax almost like your directing someone else with the controller on how to play…and overall I just found the game elements here were off putting to a story I really wanted to follow…

Graphically it stands up about as well as a game from 2009 can stand up these days though there is a noticeable dip in quality between cinematic cut scenes and in game cut scenes.

Should you watch this game? If you’re a fan of the ghostbusters it’s almost your duty to. A wonderfully crafted and well written and acted piece that almost certainly leaves a good taste in the mouth.

Should you play this game? Not unless your immune to utter pain inside…Don’t get this at full price…sale price pick it up…if nothing else for a small price you’ll get a really quite wonderful film and a near perfect “Original Trilogy” from the original creators themselves.

reviewText:
This game is worth the $10 and when it drops down below $5 during sales it should be a no brainer, especially if you are a Ghostbusters fan. The game is a linear 10 hour romp through the Ghostbusters' universe that has you facing down new and old foes alike. It is total fan service and the quality is here. With Ramis gone this is as close as you will get to a 3rd outing featuring the original cast. I enjoyed playing alongside the famous four as a rookie rather than taking control of one of the known Busters, it allows you to sit back and enjoy their antics and it really makes you feel like part of the gang and that is exactly what all of us fans dream about! Each Buster gets equal screen time and you get some one on one time with each of them at different points throughout the game. This game was a total joy.

Gamer score = 7/10
Ghostbusters fan score = 9/10

PROS

+ Ghostbusters galore. The music, sound effects, likeness of the characters, voices, writers (Aykroid and Ramis), story, it's all here folks and it's all genuine. Really, as a Ghostbusters fan, this is all you should need to know.
+ Graphics and locations. I can't believe they pulled off making us face down entities from the first movie without having it come off as cheap and gimmicky but it works here. The graphics are great but could use some tweaking to create a creepy atmosphere (it's too bright and washed out right out of the box).
+ You can replay any mission at any time to pick up any hidden items you may have missed,
+ Unlockable concept art for all the stages.
+ They take the franchise into new and interesting places. I'm a sucker for the tech and the proton packs in this game are way cooler than the originals. The PKE meter is implimented well and is fun to use as it gives you insight into the target scanned including its weaknesses. Wrangling and trapping ghosts is a blast. Cool new tools like slime tethers" that let you attach a contracting string of slime to two points in order to move stuff.
+ The game is cinematic and FUN. You really feel like you are hunting ghosts and it can get quite creepy at times though I feel like they missed a lot of opportunities to make it scary due to the lightheartedness of it all.

CONS

- The game is linear
date: straight as an arrow. There are a ton of doors you can't open and many you have to wait for your AI partner to open. No mission selection
hoursPlayed: nada. Playing this game has me dreaming of a huge open world New York
voteText:
a big Skyrim or GTA in the Ghostbusters universe.
- Mouse control is a little sloppy but you get used to it. Controls in general are a bit chunky and your path is impeded by any and all obstancles. You won't see your character hoping over benches or stepping over rubble. I blame the proton packs.
- Save feature is clunky. You must rely on autosaves and if you clock out after beating a stage (you end up back at the base after each mission) you will have started the next mission when you log in the next time. This means you will miss out on a little cutscene or two if you exit the game before viewing them after completing a mission.
- The upgrade and progression system seems tacked on and arbitrary
helpfulPercent: You get money for capturing or defeating ghosts and you use that money to upgrade the strength and resource costs of your 4 different beams
votesHelpful: traps
votesTotal: and PKE meter. You will have zero problems maxing everything out before the final mission and there is little if any visual indication that anything is stronger or better. You can't expect much in a pure shooter like this but the upgrade menu is nothing more than something you should remember to click on to make the game easier.\n- Little variety in the stages. The settings are versatile and you will fight through the streets of downtown New York

reviewText:
I really want to like this game.  It's got a good story, voice acting, and graphics.  From what I was able to play, it seems fun.

The problem is that it is plagued by a serious case of consolitis.  It was obviously made for a controller pad.  Mouse controls are so horrible, there are places you can't even turn around.  You keep getting stuck staring at the wall, ceiling, or floor, while you frustratingly try to control your character. Moving the mouse over and over again in different directions while tapping the WASD keys eventually get the mouse moving correctly again, but by that you have lost the ghost.  I've heard (but have not tried it myself) that it works fine with a 360 Controller.

Bottomline is that this may have been a fun adventure game with action elements but was ruined by a sloppy port to PC.  :P

reviewText:
It's a nice looking game.

However, for all the work that went into getting the original cast voice talent, the dialogue is just a rehash of old lines from Ghostbusters (some NEW jokes would have been nice).

More importantly, the actual gameplay stinks. The controls are sluggish and non intuitive and the bosses' difficulty seem oddly out of order. For example, Azetlor the Collector, the second real boss of the game, is the hardest boss. Speaking of boss levels, the boss design is thoroughly unimaginitive. Expose 1 weakness, hit weakness while evading. On top of that, the game will tell you the weakness right off the bat.

If it's on Steam Sale and you feel like spending a couple of dollars on it, fine. But it's certainly not worth more than a $5 mocha frappucino.

Well what do you know, Ghostbusters: The Videogame is actually a movie tie-in that doesn't suck.

Story-wise, it's Ghostbusters 3. Picking up in 1991 after the events of Ghostbusters 2, the plot centers once again on the cult of Gozer and their shennanigans. Without spoiling too much, you'll learn a lot more about Ivo Shandor, the architect who built the original temple from the first movie, and ties the plots of the first 2 movies together while telling it's own tale.
It's well-executed, with the original cast & writers at the lead. And it has the same sense of comedy & charm as the movies have.

Gameplay-wise, it's a 3rd-person shooter, with the main gimmick of having to trap a lot of ghosts instead of just blowing them up. (There are a number that need to be dispersed, aka. blown up as well for good measure). This means using the capture beams and dragging them into traps. It makes the game unique, and makes if feel like Ghostbusters. It also adds another level of franticness to the combat.
Along the way you'll find different weapon upgrades to use, you'll hunt for artifacts to collect, and you'll earn money to improve the gear you have. Throw in a few bosses that are fun to watch, if not particularly inspired in their mechanics, and you've got a solid game to go with a solid script.
There's no cover mechanics or the like, but I didn't really miss that.

It's not perfect, and the game can get frustrating if you're facing large hordes of opponents, but it's enjoyable enough. On the whole, Ghostbusters fans should NOT be giving this a miss. And neither should people who like third-person shooters with a twist.

As everyone knows, Ghostbusters is one of the biggest comedy hits of all time. 25 years later, a video game for the popular franchise was published. The player takes the role of a new rookie in the Ghostbusters team. He or she (well, the guy in the game is a he) will fight ghosts alongside with Peter Venkman (Bill Murray), Raymond Stantz (Dan Aykroyd), Egon Spengler (the late Harold Ramis) and Winston Zeddemore (Ernie Hudson).

The controls aren't the worst, but they are far from fluent. It feels bulky in the action scenes. Especially running, dashing and evading during the combat is really really stiffy stuff. Luckily, catching and fighting ghosts with the updated version of the Proton Pack isn't as hard.

Graphics and sound effects are nice. The Ghostbuster's gadgets look and sound as they should.

The story is written by Aykroyd and Ramis. The script's funny, interesting and original. It really does feel like a Ghostbusters story! The performance of the original film cast as voice actors is heart-warmingly great. It's a shame that Sigourney Weaver and Rick Moranis don't reprise their roles, though. The music is from the original 1984 movie and adds a nice touch.

Ghostbusters: The Video Game is a fun and decent game and it's a better Ghostbuster story than the third movie will ever be. It has its flaws, but it looks, sounds and most importantly feels like the Ghostbusters and that's enough for me!
