Here you play as an unnamed rookie (as every poor movie-to-videogame adaptation) in the Ghostbuster team, where you follow the title characters in the game to catch ghosts, with boring dialogues, jokes that aren't funny at all. As others had said the controls sucks and not intuitive at all, especially with keyboard+mice control, the Xbox360 controller doesn't make the game more playable and/or enjoyable. Graphically, I think it still looks okay, but the characters move quite cumbersome in the game, it doesn't matter what control you are using for the game.

The game could have been better with tactical game mechanics, perhaps similar to the Rainbow Six franchise with team based gameplay while keeping the Ghostbusters movie's fun and jokes; each team member has its unique ability to compromise other team members's weaknesses and strengths etc. The game in its current form is just too boring and the gameplay is really nothing special at all, not saying it's easy to beat the game (especially with that awful mouse accelaration that can't be disabled in the game menu). Furthermore the PC version lacks multiplayer mode!

So use your money wisely and buy an other game instead. This Ghostbusters videogame just lacks in gameplay/-gamemechanics, control, writing/story. If you want a good ghosthunting game, and if you have a Nintendo 3DS, go buy Luigi's Mansion 2 instead. Or go for the first Luigi's Mansion game for the really old Nintendo Gamecube console (a second hand Gamecube is really cheap now) for dirt cheap. As for a recommendation for the PC platform, try out Ghost Master which is also available on Steam here, though it plays differently than this Ghostbuster video game, but it's way more fun to play: just for less than 1 euro during Christmas sale!

First, I must say that I am a fan of Ghostbusters. The video game is a must for any fan who would enjoy throwing on a proton pack and catching some ghosts while haphazardly destroying the environment around them. This game has some great gameplay mechanics to catch ghosts, a good variety of enemies, and a decent addition to the storyline from the Ghostbusters movies.

Now, with that being said, the game has many flaws as well. Unfortunately for PC gamers, there is no co-op multiplayer where you get to play the campaign with your friends, unlike the console counterparts. I have no idea why this wasn't included with the PC, big mistake in my opinion. The reason for this is that the A.I. for your ghostbusting companions is very frustrating on the harder difficulties in the game. This leads to my second problem, the checkpoint system. When you fail at certain parts of the campaign because of repeated A.I. mishaps, then you have to keep going through the motions sometimes of exposition or puzzle solving over and over again just to get back to where you were. To me, those are the two main problems with the game.

Now for the good stuff. Considering the time it was released and the development and production problems that came before the game was finished, this game looks great graphically.  Fairly well polished with a lot of detail in my opinion. The star of the show being the Ghostbuster character models (which resemble their real life actors fairly well), and the famous proton pack. The detail on the proton pack is astonishing. It was a great idea to implement a HUD on the proton pack itself instead of cluttering the screen with it. Since there is no HUD cluttering the screen, this leaves room for more enjoyment in observing the destruction caused by the proton stream and other projectile particles fired from the proton pack. The destruction mechanics in the game are very fun to play with. It's just eye opening how much damage to the surrounding environment happens after a battle with a few ghosts. Sometimes, I get disappointed when I find something in the game I can't destroy. There are some levels' destructability that rival games like John Woo's Stranglehold or Red Faction Guerrilla. Also, the gameplay involved in actually catching a ghost is fun too, especially the wrangle and slam mechanics. These devices help make you feel like you've accomplished something after catching a ghost especially on the hard difficulty settings. Plus, with a decent variety of enemies, you have different ways of dispatching your foes. There is a system of advancement in the game, making your proton pack more efficient and powerful throughout the campaign. It is more of an afterthought though. The PKE segments are a cool change of pace, but unfortunately the game holds your hand too much and doesn't allow for much exploration and puzzle solving to where you actually have to figure it out. There are some good moments though where I did a get a jump scare or two.

One more plus is that the actual actors in the Ghostbusters films did the voice acting for their respective characters, at least all the main ones anyway. Plus Harold Ramis and Dan Akroyd wrote the story and script for the game so it's legit.

Ghostbusters:  The Videogame is a must play for fans and for anyone interested in a fun third person shooter that differs a bit from most of the TPS's out there. This game could have been soooo much more in the long run if the developers had more time to work on the gameplay mechanics and how to integrate them into a more open world exploration approach. If this game wasn't so linear and didn't hold your hand so much on the puzzle solving and directing where the player must go, and then maybe adding some driving of Ecto-1 so a little bit of an open world approach can play out, then it would be a AAA game in my book. But, this is what we get and I'm glad that the Ghostbusters can be alive and well in a decent video game.

The good:

Long Version:
I decided to give this a go due to all the positive reviews. At first I quite enjoyed it, catching your first ghost is great and visting old locations from the movies. The dreaded AI was manageable....at first. Then it quickly descended into game breaking frustration, especially on the hardest difficulty. As the game gets more challening later on with more ghosts with harder mechanics your teamates go down more and more and it becomes a pain. I am a massive ghostbusters fan so I tried to grind through all this, but I could only take it so far before I couldn't put up with it. Even without the shoddy AI the game still isn't fantastic. While the rest of the gameplay is fine, it's very linear, gets too repetitive later on, taking on the same ghosts over and over and the story isn't completely gripping, as it re-treads the first movie and is predicatable.

Great little game for all you Ghostbusters fans out there. All the characters and devices are instantly recognizeable and there're lots of references to movies. Maybe even too much, even for fan service. As a game it's not far from mediocre. The graphics, the most important aspect of any game then and now, are nice, while the combat system is dull and gets old really quickly even with all the upgrades you can buy. I recommend a controller, since two of my computers had jerky controls with mouse and keyboard for some reason.

You are literally walking inside the famous (or infamous) firehouse, sliding down the pole and getting into the Ecto-1 to do battle with ghosts that challenge your Proton-pack, along with all the other cool gadgets that do not become excessive, but are introduced gradually and enhance your enjoyment of the game.  I would say about 50% of my enjoyment of this game stems from my appreciation for the film as a child - if you're a fan of the movies, you will appreciate this game.  They've done justice.  I feel like I'm 5 years old again and living my dream as an actual teammember!  It's really cool.  One thing they could have done was increase the intervals between savepoints (I'm playing on hard - I am, afterall, a real Ghostbuster); but you'll get better at the game and get over this before too long. Pros

* Just like the (original) movie, gags, references, memes and all.
* Colourful (love the proton streams!), beautiful, scenic.
* Storyline is a continuation from the movie/s, but not identical - expands and evolves it - really well done and draws you in.
* Fairly immersive and shiny (in particular when you cross over to the Gozer dimension...wow!)
* Loads of light-hearted fun and inside GB jokes.
* Not very laggy or performance heavy.
* Fantastic music score - just like the movies!
* Voice-overs by all original cast members and including special guest Alyssa Milano as Dr. Ilyssa (LOL!) Selwyn :)

Cons

*  Not very creepy but it tries to on several occasions - has its moments it caught me off-guard.
*  Missing achievements and trading cards.
* Few bugs (Ghosts or teammates getting stuck / collisions/ logic and not progressing storyline) forcing you to reload from last save.
* Some of the animations are really well done and others you can just tell there was 0 effort.

Conclusion

Despite it's drawbacks, it was still definitely worth the cost. None of the cons were significant enough to make me want to not see it through to the end. Very fun and gets challenging on harder difficulties. Great that you can change difficulty without starting the entire game over.
If you liked the (original) movie, it is highly recommended you give it a go for fun - you won't be dissapointed. The only real dissapointment was the lack of achievements (in game or steam) and lack of steam trading cards.

As everyone knows, Ghostbusters is one of the biggest comedy hits of all time. 25 years later, a video game for the popular franchise was published. The player takes the role of a new rookie in the Ghostbusters team. He or she (well, the guy in the game is a he) will fight ghosts alongside with Peter Venkman (Bill Murray), Raymond Stantz (Dan Aykroyd), Egon Spengler (the late Harold Ramis) and Winston Zeddemore (Ernie Hudson).

The controls aren't the worst, but they are far from fluent. It feels bulky in the action scenes. Especially running, dashing and evading during the combat is really really stiffy stuff. Luckily, catching and fighting ghosts with the updated version of the Proton Pack isn't as hard.

Graphics and sound effects are nice. The Ghostbuster's gadgets look and sound as they should.

The story is written by Aykroyd and Ramis. The script's funny, interesting and original. It really does feel like a Ghostbusters story! The performance of the original film cast as voice actors is heart-warmingly great. It's a shame that Sigourney Weaver and Rick Moranis don't reprise their roles, though. The music is from the original 1984 movie and adds a nice touch.

Ghostbusters: The Video Game is a fun and decent game and it's a better Ghostbuster story than the third movie will ever be. It has its flaws, but it looks, sounds and most importantly feels like the Ghostbusters and that's enough for me!

TO ANYONE GETTING ERROR MESSAGE GHOST_32: I was terrified that the game was incompatable with my PC when I had two days of issues with it, the solution is just to make certain you have no controllers of any kind (not just 360) plugged in while booting. I mention this so if someone else winds up in my spot it'll save them a lotta time and system digging.

I'm currently 8 hours into this one, and the game is fantastic. I enjoyed the first film but wouldn't consider myself a diehard fan, but even as a newbie to the franchise the gameplay lets this title stand on its own. The third person three-step process to ghostbusting is a ton of fun and can get very frantic and exciting. The controls are... a bit stiff but I find with this sort of game it works, like tank controls did for older survival horror where managing to work in the framework of the game is part of the challenge and fun. The 'weapons' are all very satisfying, and I spent way more time and had way more fun just pinning chairs to the rooves of buildings with the slime tether than I should be willing to admit.

The soundtrack matches the film with some great atmospheric pieces put in, and most pleasantly: The game is actually quite unsettling at a few points. I was worried with the brand image they'd hold back on the spooky side but the game actually got a few jumps out of me and the ghost design ranges from goofy to actually hellish.

I would check on your specs before purchasing, the game runs pretty good on my system but there is an abundance of particle effects that I've found my fps greatly drop during, particularly in the ghost world level, Also in the kitchen level where there was a lot of fire and smoke going on.

Back to audio, the original voice cast is almost entirely here, and they sound fantastic. You play as a generic silent protaganist which is a bit disappointing since I saw a golden opportunity to get a recognized voice today play a new addition to the team that could add more banter, but messing with the original formula is iffy business so I can understand playing it safe.

Ultimately you have a 10 hour game with a good amount of collectables, great third person shooter gameplay, an often tense atmosphere, and a good amount of weapons. You also get ten hours with Bill Murray, and if that doesn't buy you alone it's probably not the game for you. The story is pretty good as well but a bit tough to follow. It may be because I have never seen Ghostbusters 2. Either way, solid game, having a ton of fun with it aside from some mild issues. If I had to ascribe a number it'd be a very recommended 8.

If you haven't already picked up this game and happen to be a Ghostbusters fan, do yourself a favor and get it.\nThe script for this video game was rewritten from an old draft for Ghostbusters 3, so it's considered to be canon in the timeline of the series, and the closest we'll get to a sequel of Ghostbusters 2.\nNot only that, but a majority of the cast from both films returned, lending their voices while the characters resemble how they appeared in 1991. Lastly, it's one of the few very good licensed games, so that alone makes it worth the buy.

In a nutshell: Yes, this game lets you be a Ghostbuster, and yes, it's pretty damn cool. That said, the performance is atrocious. It feels like you need to have a certain graphics config, or have your computer built a certain way.

The game itself is very nice. Graphics are lacking, mostly in character models, but proton beams and ghosts are animated perfectly. As for the story, I obviously haven't beaten it within this release, but from playing it on consoles, I can confirm that it's suffecient. Maybe not a masterpiece of storytelling, but pretty good nonetheless.

Controls actually aren't a problem, they're very straight forward and easy to remember, but the game runs awfully. Like, distractingly so. To the point where it's hard to play for more than 30 minutes at a time without the right PC build or configuration. This is the major drawback of the PC release. If possible, play this game on a PS3 or Xbox 360. The expierence is quite a bit better there (If nothing else, I recommend a controller).

Overall, the game itself is great, but due to performance, it feels coated in ♥♥♥♥. Like I said, try and play the console release if possible, but if you can't and you're a big fan of the franchise, then go for this. It's certainly not impossible to enjoy on PC, and if you can tweak your settings and find a way to make it run properly, then it's even better.

Game itself gets an 8/10, after performance, drops to a 6-7/10.

This is an awesome game especially if you are a fan of the original movie.
The Story was written by Dan Akroid and Harold Ramis, and the rest of the original actors from the first movie do the voices for all the characters.
To me the story feels like a true sequel to the original movie; I really liked the inner jokes, and the overall attitude of the characters, they seem to be true to the movie.
If you are not a fan of the movie, or Bill Murray, you might get frustrated during the first chapter, but if you give it a chance and push through it, you might enjoy the rest of the game, it does get better and easier with the upgrades.
The controls are a little difficult to use on a couple of the fights, but they are spread apart enough to become too difficult or frustrating. Once you get past the first couple of hours and you get a good handle on the controls it is smooth for the most part.
The only thing I really didn't like was that there are areas where you don't know what to do, it is not very intuitive what to do next, and you have to try a few things before one of your companions suggest something and then you have to figure out how to solve the puzzle with the vague clue that they give you.
I played with a 360 control, and getting used to it took me a while before I got comfortable with the weapons and how to combine and use the buttons correctly.
Overall I really liked the game, took me around 20 hours to play through it, spread out over a few weekends.
The game is definitely worth the prize, if not the game just for the story and voice acting.

If you are a Ghostbusters fan, the odds are that you will love this game. I feel that the devs were truly able to capture the feeling of being a ghostbuster and being part of the team in that universe. I've owned the game for at least four years and I've played through it about 6 times and love it every time.

The game has fantastic atmosphere. Every place has good aesthetics including some places that are genuinely creepy. You get to revisit some classic movie locations, done well I might add. The writing and voice acting is a pleasure (though some say Murray's voice acting was half hearted, judge for yourself) and the familiar GB humor is present throughout the game. Not to mention the iconic music! Not just the obvious themesong, but the same music that was composed by Elmer Bernstein that sets the mood in every scene in the movie.

Dan Aykroyd himself has said that the game is basically the third movie, so if you are aching for a continuation of the story line with the same familiar faces and voices then I suggest you give the game a playthrough.

For me, as a ghosthead, the replayability of this game is as high as rewatchability of the movies (at least the first one) which I've watched many, many times.

As you can see I love this game, but it is not without its flaws. At least one area of the game dropped my FPS to single digits on my old computer, but I haven't had the issue with my current computer with max settings on. The mouse aiming is wonky; It feels unoptimized and possibly mouse acceleration is stuck on, but the controller feels good. Certain parts of the game are only hard because they're frustrating and, related to that, sometimes you get stuck with the job of constantly picking up your team because you depend on them to pick you up if you get knocked down.

The game can give you around 8 hours of gameplay but that's if you move at the game's pace while picking up collectibles. It's possible to beat the game in half of that time.

The most sacriligious thing is that the multiplayer half the the game was excluded for the PC version. If you are intent on playing with your friends then you need to buy the console version.

Also, a side note, BUY THE GAME WHILE YOU CAN! I don't know what the deal is, but this game seems to have a history of popping up on Steam and then disappearing for years.

I also recommend not purchasing the ghost trap upgrades. My favorite part of the game is wrangling and capturing ghosts with the crew and I don't want anything that detracts from that. If you do decide not to get the upgrades but you are worried that the game may be too hard without them, I've beaten the game three times on professional difficulty and I've never purchased the trap upgrades once.

reviewText: Bustin' makes me feel good!

Very disappointed! Thought it would be great fun, especially when it was on sale. A typical adaptation from a movie franchise to a video game that fails to capture the feel and atmosphere of the original Ghostbusters movies. This game is rather boring and uninspired. The only good thing about the game is the main theme song! Here you play as an unnamed rookie (as every poor movie-to-videogame adaptation) in the Ghostbuster team, where you follow the title characters in the game to catch ghosts, with boring dialogues, jokes that aren't funny at all. As others had said the controls sucks and not intuitive at all, especially with keyboard+mice control, the Xbox360 controller doesn't make the game more playable and/or enjoyable. Graphically, I think it still looks okay, but the characters move quite cumbersome in the game, it doesn't matter what control you are using for the game.

The game could have been better with tactical game mechanics, perhaps similar to the Rainbow Six franchise with team based gameplay while keeping the Ghostbusters movie's fun and jokes; each team member has its unique ability to compromise other team members's weaknesses and strengths etc. The game in its current form is just too boring and the gameplay is really nothing special at all, not saying it's easy to beat the game (especially with that awful mouse accelaration that can't be disabled in the game menu). Furthermore the PC version lacks multiplayer mode!

So use your money wisely and buy an other game instead. This Ghostbusters videogame just lacks in gameplay/-gamemechanics, control, writing/story. If you want a good ghosthunting game, and if you have a Nintendo 3DS, go buy Luigi's Mansion 2 instead. Or go for the first Luigi's Mansion game for the really old Nintendo Gamecube console (a second hand Gamecube is really cheap now) for dirt cheap. As for a recommendation for the PC platform, try out Ghost Master which is also available on Steam here, though it plays differently than this Ghostbuster video game, but it's way more fun to play: just for less than 1 euro during Christmas sale!

A surprisingly solid late-2000's third-person shooter that honors the source material and lets you play around in the Ghostbusters' world. Competent, refined mechanics, decent-to-good art direction, and a great set of VO performances from Ramis, Ackroyd, and Hudson. Murray sours the deal with one of the most phoned-in performances of all time - which is a shame. Functionally, this game is an interactive Ghostbusters III. It's a fine nostalgia piece for the nerd generation that almost overstays its welcome. Until it does, though, it lathers you in good-natured fan service. Worth it on sale or for an afternoon when you want to relive running around in a backpack and a vacuum cleaner hose catching ghosts" (which strongly resemble your family pets)."

Once you get to the end of the story you probably won't care anymore and will inevitably load up the first hotel level to destroy furniture with the ghost laser gun. The pack upgrades are cool but ultimately only serve a gameplay mechanic. There's very little choice, the game handholds, and overall it feels like it's from a bygone era (which it is). If you're a fan of the franchise, it's very much worth buying. There's Easter eggs galore for fans and the game play is very well done.

You play alongside the original 4, with the original voice actors, as a rookie trying to learn the ropes and earn your spot in the Ghost busters. Set just after the events of 2, all of New York is threatened a third time as Gozer tee's up for a second stab at world ending chaos.

The voice acting is well done, with Annie Potts and William Atherton also making a comeback as Janine and Walter peck respectively. this helps the world feel very much like a third sequal, with the aesthetics matching that of the movies. While the graphics aren't setting the world on fire, they are still very good.

With the franchise about to take a turn away from what is already beloved, into something good or bad, this serves as a nice escape to forget what's ahead or visit down retro road for those who want more of the originals.

If you are a Ghostbusters fan, the odds are that you will love this game. I feel that the devs were truly able to capture the feeling of being a ghostbuster and being part of the team in that universe. I've owned the game for at least four years and I've played through it about 6 times and love it every time.

The game has fantastic atmosphere. Every place has good aesthetics including some places that are genuinely creepy. You get to revisit some classic movie locations, done well I might add. The writing and voice acting is a pleasure (though some say Murray's voice acting was half hearted, judge for yourself) and the familiar GB humor is present throughout the game. Not to mention the iconic music! Not just the obvious themesong, but the same music that was composed by Elmer Bernstein that sets the mood in every scene in the movie.

Dan Aykroyd himself has said that the game is basically the third movie, so if you are aching for a continuation of the story line with the same familiar faces and voices then I suggest you give the game a playthrough.

For me, as a ghosthead, the replayability of this game is as high as rewatchability of the movies (at least the first one) which I've watched many, many times.

As you can see I love this game, but it is not without its flaws. At least one area of the game dropped my FPS to single digits on my old computer, but I haven't had the issue with my current computer with max settings on. The mouse aiming is wonky; It feels unoptimized and possibly mouse acceleration is stuck on, but the controller feels good. Certain parts of the game are only hard because they're frustrating and, related to that, sometimes you get stuck with the job of constantly picking up your team because you depend on them to pick you up if you get knocked down.

The game can give you around 8 hours of gameplay but that's if you move at the game's pace while picking up collectibles. It's possible to beat the game in half of that time.

The most sacriligious thing is that the multiplayer half the the game was excluded for the PC version. If you are intent on playing with your friends then you need to buy the console version.

Also, a side note, BUY THE GAME WHILE YOU CAN! I don't know what the deal is, but this game seems to have a history of popping up on Steam and then disappearing for years.

I also recommend not purchasing the ghost trap upgrades. My favorite part of the game is wrangling and capturing ghosts with the crew and I don't want anything that detracts from that. If you do decide not to get the upgrades but you are worried that the game may be too hard without them, I've beaten the game three times on professional difficulty and I've never purchased the trap upgrades once.

I don't think Ghostbuster fans are ever going to get another game, or even a movie, that is as good as this game. Take that how ever you want to.

First, I must say that I am a fan of Ghostbusters. The video game is a must for any fan who would enjoy throwing on a proton pack and catching some ghosts while haphazardly destroying the environment around them. This game has some great gameplay mechanics to catch ghosts, a good variety of enemies, and a decent addition to the storyline from the Ghostbusters movies.

Now, with that being said, the game has many flaws as well. Unfortunately for PC gamers, there is no co-op multiplayer where you get to play the campaign with your friends, unlike the console counterparts. I have no idea why this wasn't included with the PC, big mistake in my opinion. The reason for this is that the A.I. for your ghostbusting companions is very frustrating on the harder difficulties in the game. This leads to my second problem, the checkpoint system. When you fail at certain parts of the campaign because of repeated A.I. mishaps, then you have to keep going through the motions sometimes of exposition or puzzle solving over and over again just to get back to where you were. To me, those are the two main problems with the game.

Now for the good stuff. Considering the time it was released and the development and production problems that came before the game was finished, this game looks great graphically.  Fairly well polished with a lot of detail in my opinion. The star of the show being the Ghostbuster character models (which resemble their real life actors fairly well), and the famous proton pack. The detail on the proton pack is astonishing. It was a great idea to implement a HUD on the proton pack itself instead of cluttering the screen with it. Since there is no HUD cluttering the screen, this leaves room for more enjoyment in observing the destruction caused by the proton stream and other projectile particles fired from the proton pack. The destruction mechanics in the game are very fun to play with. It's just eye opening how much damage to the surrounding environment happens after a battle with a few ghosts. Sometimes, I get disappointed when I find something in the game I can't destroy. There are some levels' destructability that rival games like John Woo's Stranglehold or Red Faction Guerrilla. Also, the gameplay involved in actually catching a ghost is fun too, especially the wrangle and slam mechanics. These devices help make you feel like you've accomplished something after catching a ghost especially on the hard difficulty settings. Plus, with a decent variety of enemies, you have different ways of dispatching your foes. There is a system of advancement in the game, making your proton pack more efficient and powerful throughout the campaign. It is more of an afterthought though. The PKE segments are a cool change of pace, but unfortunately the game holds your hand too much and doesn't allow for much exploration and puzzle solving to where you actually have to figure it out. There are some good moments though where I did a get a jump scare or two.

One more plus is that the actual actors in the Ghostbusters films did the voice acting for their respective characters, at least all the main ones anyway. Plus Harold Ramis and Dan Akroyd wrote the story and script for the game so it's legit.

Ghostbusters:  The Videogame is a must play for fans and for anyone interested in a fun third person shooter that differs a bit from most of the TPS's out there. This game could have been soooo much more in the long run if the developers had more time to work on the gameplay mechanics and how to integrate them into a more open world exploration approach. If this game wasn't so linear and didn't hold your hand so much on the puzzle solving and directing where the player must go, and then maybe adding some driving of Ecto-1 so a little bit of an open world approach can play out, then it would be a AAA game in my book. But, this is what we get and I'm glad that the Ghostbusters can be alive and well in a decent video game.

reviewText:
For many people 30 years have passed and there is still no Ghostbusters 3. But I like to think of this game as Ghostbusters 3. While playing this I had an abosolute blast! There has been no game to date that captures the charm and brillience of Ghostbusters as well as this.
Pros:
All voices actors (besides Rick Moranis) return and give the same level of charm that they did in the movies.
The gameplay is fun and engaging, wrangling ghosts and trapping them is a great experience and would be a reason alone to buy this game.
The graphics are extremely well done (especially by 2009 standards) and bring the world to life.
The story has great humour, plot twists and structure.
The level design is excellent (I could spend hours exploring every single detail in the levels).
The game has good replay value and even afterwards you'll still have cursed objects to collect and ghosts to scan.
Cons:
You are bound to only 1 place at a time, the story narrates where you go and when you go there (it would be great if at some point someone would make a RPG Ghostbusters game where you travel around the city answering calls).
If you turn off the game while at the firehouse, it cancels out the next cutscene when you reload it.
You sometimes have to stand in an exact spot for a command to activate and move the gameplay along (for example, when in the library, the ghost didn't appear until I stood in an exact spot).
In conclusion, this is an amazing game, if you're a fan of Ghostbusters, this game is a must, it also ran very smoothly on my PC (which doesn't do too well with games). 8.0/10 Amazing!

reviewText: Loved this game from start to finish, excellent story would highly recommend!

A game for Ghostbusters fans!

I loved Ghostbusters as a kid and its still one of my favorite movies.  The game is a great adventure that acts as a third movie.  It has the original cast doing the voice work and script credited to Dan Aykroyd and Harold Ramis!  It's awesome seeing these characters interact as you join them as the silent rookie.

Gameplay is good as far as using the classic gear and catching ghosts like the movie.  However it isn't the best.  Enemies can swarm and corner you.  You'll have to constantly revive your teammates because you'll need them to revive you! You collect money to upgrade equipment, but you'll have it all about halfway through the game.  I think a little tweaks like customization of your character appearance, more interaction with the firehouse, more stuff to purchase with the money you earn would have been nice.

Be warned, it isn't a very long game.  You can unlock the concept artwork which will make you just a little sad of what was cut out.  I was happy with what I got, but can't help wondering how much more it could have been.

All in all, worthwhile for your Ghostbuster fix.  Not a fan, you may not enjoy it unless you want a fun story.

reviewText:
Early review.

I bought this on sale a number of years ago and never really dusted it off. Today I played it for about 7.5 hours. Let me clear up a few misconceptions. It works fine in Windows 10, and the in game support for an X-bOX 360 controller works just fine. Don't believe the junk posts in the forums.

I don't recommend you spend a lot of money on this game. Its an average port. It has decent, if not a little dated graphics and the voice actors are by the original actors (voice acting is actually quite good). There's also been a fair amount of attention to detail paid to the original two movies.

The game play is average but still fun. I would suggest playing it on casual and just enjoying the story and some moderately challenging fights. Beating them on hard mode won't lend you much in the way of a sense of accomplishment (especially without achievements). If you look at buying this like renting a movie, only you get to keep it, you'll be just fine.
The best ghostbusters video game.

Easily the best licensed game I've ever played.  Great voice cast (since it's the original cast), great visuals (for the time), and a pretty cool plot.

Controls are so-so and a little sluggish, but it's kind of appropriate considering you're playing a doughy guy lugging around over a hundred pounds of equipment.

The power-ups are pretty damn fun, and are well within the wheelhouse of our proton pack heroes.

Pick it up if you find it on sale.  It's definitely worth the play.  If you're a ghostbusters fan, you may go back for seconds (or thirds).

Ghostbusters is my favorite movie, so I may have a bit of bias here, but I really enjoyed this game. It was great to hear and see the gang get back together. It really does feel like you a Ghostbuster in this game, and the story was good enough that it could of been Ghostbusters 3.

What I really enjoyed about this game is the voice acting by the original cast members, especially the now-passed Harold Ramis (who also co-wrote it, along with Dan Aykroyd).  The cutscenes and banter between the ghostbusters feels very much like one of the movies, and in fact this game is largely considered canon in the Ghostbusters universe.

The designers also did a pretty good job of capturing the actors' faces digitally, even if it's starting to look a little dated.

The game itself is fairly simple and linear, but the action is challenging enough to make it feel like you've earned the next cutscene of the movie/game you're watching/playing.

I'm only a few hours in, but... if you love GB, take your money and buy this instead of going to see the new thing. There's a cool vibe here where you feel like you're hanging out with the original cast. The mechanics aren't super complicated, but they create a simulation where you're wrangling ghosts, actually forcing them into your trap. The destruction you cause is awesome -- puts you into the hotel scene throughout the whole game. Plus, they do a great job letting you experience the original ghosts without forgetting the original movie or outright copying it. The models look slightly stiff and dated during cutscenes, but that's easy to forgive with the voice cast and the cool creepiness of ghost hunting, where you're heading down a dark hall and furniture starts to rise. Also, the PC version really, REALLY needs multiplayer -- you can tell it would be a perfect fit. Still, it's easily worth the 10 bucks.
